summary: The document outlines the operations of The Information Council of the Americas (INCA), an organization dedicated to countering Communist influence by distributing anti-Communist materials, specifically Truth Tapes, to radio stations across Latin and North America. It highlights the involvement of Edward Scannell Butler, INCA's executive vice president, in intelligence gathering efforts regarding radio broadcasting stations and their audiences. The memo also addresses the difficulties encountered in obtaining detailed political information and proposes modifications to questionnaires to enhance data collection efficiency without drawing undue attention.
key_findings: INCA was created to oppose Communist influence in the Americas via anti-Communist radio broadcasts.
Edward Scannell Butler was instrumental in INCA's activities, managing communications with radio stations and overseeing the distribution of Truth Tapes.
Challenges were faced in collecting in-depth political and technical data on radio stations discreetly.
Proposals were made to adjust questionnaires for better intelligence gathering, possibly with support from external agencies.
